tgt_lang: BETWEEN TRADITIONAL LANGUAGE AND MODERN LANGUAGE

src_lang: ‘Gramer’ : ala enn mo ki souvan fer dimounn per
tgt_lang: 'Grammar': a word that often makes people fearful

src_lang: Dan lespri boukou, li enn zafer konplike, ki fatig latet, ki aprann dan lekol, ki bon pou bann ki kontan lir ek ekrir, ouswa ki bizin fer li
tgt_lang: "In many minds, it is a complex matter, exhausting for the brain, learned in school, good for those who enjoy reading and writing, or those who need to do it"

src_lang: Li bon pou zanfan lekol; li bon pou profeser lang, pou bann intelektiel, bann ekrivin, et c
tgt_lang: "It is good for school children; it is good for language teachers, for intellectuals, writers, etc."

src_lang: Me pa oblize konn li, ouswa aprann li, pou fer konversasion ordiner
tgt_lang: "But it is not necessary to know it, or to learn it, for everyday conversation"

src_lang: Ena ousi dimounn ki panse ki zis bann lang ki servi pou ekrir ki ena gramer
tgt_lang: There are also people who think that only languages used for writing have grammar

src_lang: Ki bann lang ki itilize sirtou pou koze, kouma laplipar bann lang kreol ki finn servi ziska ler, zot pena gramer
tgt_lang: "Languages primarily used for speaking, like most Creole languages that have been used up to now, do not have grammar"

src_lang: Enn kestion souvan revini isi: kouma enn lang kot sakenn pe koz so fason, pe pronons bann mo dan so manier, pe ekrir (kan lokazion prezante) dan bann kod grafik personel ek diferan, kouma sa lang‐la kapav ena gramer? Anfet, mazorite dimounn pa kone exakteman ki vedir ‘gramer’
tgt_lang: "A question that often arises here: how can a language where everyone speaks their way, pronounces words in their own way, writes (when required) in personal and different graphic codes, how can that language have grammar? In fact, the majority of people do not exactly know what 'grammar' means"

src_lang: An realite, ena bouk ou konfizion otour sinifikasion mo‐la limem, e se sa konfizion ‐la, dan boukou laspe, ki responsab bann move interpretasion ek move reprezantasion ki dimounn ena lor nosion gramer
tgt_lang: "In reality, there is a lot of confusion about the meaning of the word 'grammar', and it is this confusion, in many cases, that is responsible for the bad interpretations and representations that people have about the notion of grammar"

src_lang: Se pou sa rezon‐la ki li neseser koumans nou reflexion lor gramer Kreol Morisyen par enn interogasion lor bann diferan sinifikason ki term ‘gramer’ finn ena ziska ler
tgt_lang: For this reason, it is necessary to start our reflection on the grammar of Mauritian Creole through an interrogation on the different meanings that the term "grammar" has had up to now.

src_lang: Lorizinn term ‘gramer’ Term ‘gramer’ sorti depi mo grek “grammatike” ki vedir ‘lar ki permet dimounn lir ek ekrir kouma bizin ’
tgt_lang: The origin of the term "grammar" comes from the Greek word "grammatike" which means 'the art that allows people to read and write as needed'.

src_lang: Mem si finn ena diferan sistem, depi lorizinn lekritir ( an avan nou lepok dan Lorian), kot finn montre dimounn kouma ekrir, se bann Grek ki finn devlop an premie, enn konsians lor ki ete gramer, dan sans ki nou fin n konpran li dan lepok modern, avek klasifikasion bann mo an kategori, deskripsion bann reg pou kontriksion fraz, pou konzigezon verb, etc
tgt_lang: "Even though there were different systems, starting from the origin of writing (before our time in Mauritius), where people were taught how to write, it was the Greeks who first developed an awareness of what grammar is, in the sense that we understand it in modern times, with the classification of words into categories, description of rules for sentence construction, verb conjugation, etc."

src_lang: Zot ti fer li pou enn rezon presi, ki ti lie ek prezervasion ‘pirte’ lang grek, tel ki li pratike dan pe ryod antik, sirtou dan lepok Homère (ki bann Grek konsidere kouma premie poet ki Lerop finn kone)
tgt_lang: "They did it for a precise reason, which was linked to the preservation of the purity of the Greek language, as practiced in ancient times, especially in the time of Homer (whom the Greeks consider as the first poet known in Europe)."

src_lang: Bann Grek finn touletan konsider sa lepok‐la kouma laz‐dor lang grek
tgt_lang: The Greeks have always considered that period as the golden age of the Greek language.

src_lang: Me ver lafin lanpir grek, bann lotorite finn konsidere ki nivo zot lang ti pe koumans ‘dekline’ ek perdi so val er par pratik bann zenn zenerasion ek par ‘kontaminasion’ ek bann lezot lang
tgt_lang: "However, with the decline in the use of the Greek language, authorities considered that the level of their language was beginning to decline and lose its value by the practice of the following generations and by the contamination with other languages."

src_lang: Li ti vinn neseser dekrir ek ekrir bann reg ki ti pou permet bann zenn zenerasion kone kouma bizin bien koze ek ekrir kan zot servi lang grek
tgt_lang: It became necessary to describe and write rules that would allow future generations to know how to speak and write correctly when using the Greek language.

src_lang: Se bann ansien text ki ti ekrir lepok klasik ki ti servi kou ma enn referans pou deskripsion langaz‐la ek fourni bann reg pou kone kouma pou itiliz li dan enn fason korek
tgt_lang: Old texts written during classical times served as a reference for the description of the language and provided rules for knowing how to use it correctly.

src_lang: Term “grammaire” finn fer so aparision an Franse depi e siek kot li finn koumans pran diferan sinifikasion, an fonksion lepok, sistem panse, ouswa teori lingwistik ki dimounn swazir pou adopte
tgt_lang: "The term 'grammar' made its appearance in French since the sixteenth century when it began to take on different meanings, depending on the era, the mode of thought, or the linguistic theories that people chose to adopt."

src_lang: Apartir sa moman‐la, sinifikasion « grammaire » ti nepli limit li ek lir ek ekrir me ti konsern ousi laparol
tgt_lang: "From that moment, the meaning of 'grammar' was no longer limited to reading and writing, but also concerned speech."

src_lang: Pou Arnauld ek Lancelot, bann loter La Grammaire de Port Royale ( ), gramer ti vinn sinonim ek “l’art de parler ”
tgt_lang: " For Arnauld and Lancelot, the authors of the book La Grammaire de Port Royale ( ), grammar became synonymous with “the art of speaking”"

src_lang: En , Dictionnaire de l’Académie definir gramer kouma “l’Art de parler et d’écrire correctement ”
tgt_lang: "In , the Dictionnaire de l’Académie defined grammar as “the Art of speaking and writing correctly”"

src_lang: Sa definision ‐la finn repran par boukou diksioner depi sa lepok‐la
tgt_lang: This definition has been taken up by many dictionaries since that time

src_lang: Diksioner Littré, par exanp, dir nou ki gramer, se “l'art d’exprimer ses pensées par la pa role ou par l’écriture d’une manière conforme aux règles établies par le bon usage ” alor ki Le Grand Robert dir nou ki sa mo‐la vedir “[l’]ensemble de[s] règles à suivre pour parler et écrire correctement une langue ”
tgt_lang: "For example, Littré's dictionary tells us that grammar is “the art of expressing thoughts through speech or writing in a manner conforming to the rules established by good usage" whereas Le Grand Robert tells us that it means "[the] set of rules to follow in order to speak and write a language correctly"

src_lang: An zeneral, se sa lapros‐la ki finn transmet depi enn zenerasion ziska enn lot dan lekol, e se ousi sa lapros‐la ki finn debous lor seki finn apel plitar “grammaire traditionnelle” (‘gramer tradisionel’ an Kreol)
tgt_lang: "In general, it is this approach that has been passed down from one generation to another in schools, and it is also this approach that has been criticized for what is called the "traditional grammar" (‘gramer tradisionel’ in Creole)"

src_lang: Gramer tradisionel Kan koz gramer tradisionel, an zeneral, pe fer referans ek enn tip gramer ki ena trwa karakteristik prinsipal
tgt_lang: "Traditional Grammar When talking about traditional grammar, in general, reference is made to a type of grammar with three main characteristics"

src_lang: (i) Li enn gramer normatif Par ‘normatif’ nou rod dir ki Gramer tradisionel fer enn distinksion ant bann bon fason pou ekrir ek koz enn lang, ek bann fason ki pa korek
tgt_lang: "(i) It is a normative grammar By ‘normative’ we mean that Traditional Grammar makes a distinction between correct and incorrect ways of writing and speaking a language"

src_lang: Li inpoz bann reg san ki li pran an kont evolision langaz, diversite bann pratik ek varyasion so itilizasion dan lavi reel
tgt_lang: It imposes rules without taking into account the evolution of language, the diversity of practices, and variations in its use in real life"

src_lang: Lekol, se landrwa privilizie kot aprann gr amer normatif avek soutien bann liv ek bann text referans
tgt_lang: "School is the privileged place where normative grammar is taught with the support of books and reference texts"

src_lang: (ii) Li akord plis linportans lekritir ki laparol Gramer tradisionel pran lekritir, e non laparol, kouma baz referans pou dekrir bann reg enn lang
tgt_lang: "(ii) It gives more importance to writing than to speaking Traditional Grammar focuses on writing, not speaking, as the basis for describing the rules of a language"

src_lang: Gramer modern Dabor nou bizin koumans par presize ki expresion ‘gramer modern’ pa fer referans ar enn sel gramer me plizier
tgt_lang: Modern Grammar

src_lang: Nou apel zot ‘modern’ parski zot finn aparet apre gramer tradisionel e finn definir laplipar parmi zot an konparezon ek gramer tradisionel
tgt_lang: We call them 'modern' because they have appeared after traditional grammar and have defined themselves mostly by comparison with traditional grammar

src_lang: Parmi bann gramer ki rant dan kategori gramer modern, nou ena: (i) Bann gramer striktiral Nou apel ‘gramer striktiral’ tou bann gramer ki inspire par lingwistik striktiral
tgt_lang: "Among the grammars that fall into the category of modern grammar, we have: (i) Structural grammars We also call 'structural grammar' all grammars inspired by structural linguistics"

src_lang: Dan sa kategori‐la nou retrouv sirtou de gran tandans: ( ) gramer distribisionel (Bloomfield, Harris, Hocket); ( ) gramer zeneratif ek transformasionel (Chomsky) ki enn prolonzman gramer distribisionel
tgt_lang: "In this category, we find especially two major trends: ( ) distributive grammar (Bloomfield, Harris, Hocket); ( ) generative and transformational grammar (Chomsky) as an extension of distributive grammar"

src_lang: Ena ousi bann lezot term ki servi pou dezign sa bann gramer‐la: gra mer formel; gramer sintagmatik; gramer sintaxik, etc
tgt_lang: "There are also other terms used to designate these grammars: formal grammar; syntagmatic grammar; syntactic grammar, etc"

src_lang: Pwin komin ki ena ek tou sa bann gramer‐la, seki zot etidie gramer apartir form ek striktir bann fraz ki prodir dan lang ki zot pe dekrir e zot analiz bann mo apartir plas ek rol ki zot ena dan bann fraz‐la (get detay pli lwin, sapit
tgt_lang: "A common point for all these grammars is that they study grammar from the form and structure of sentences produced in the language they are describing and analyze words based on the place and role they have in these sentences"

src_lang: (ii) Bann gramer laparol Bann gramer laparol interes zot sirtou ek kominikasion: zot met an evidans bann akt ki bann dimounn (rod) akonplir kan zot adres zot ek enn ou lezot dimounn: salitasion, remersiman, rod linformasion, donn linformasion, siplikasion, komandman, intimidasion, etc
tgt_lang: "(ii) Oral grammars Oral grammars are mainly interested in communication: they highlight the actions that individuals perform when they address one another: greetings, thanks, seeking information, giving information, explanations, commands, intimidations, etc"

src_lang: Pou sakenn sa bann akt‐la, ena bann kategori sintaxik ouswa stilistik ki pou korespo nn e ki bann lokiter enn lang bizin kone ek metrize pou zot kapav kominike
tgt_lang: "For each of these actions, there are syntactic or stylistic categories that need to correspond to and that individuals need to know and master in order to communicate"

src_lang: Bann gramer laparol interes zot ek idantifikasion ek analiz sa bann kategori‐la
tgt_lang: Oral grammars are interested in identifying and analyzing these categories

src_lang: Parmi bann gramer ki rant dan fami gramer laparol, nou retrouv: gramer lenonsiasion, gramer diskour, gramer akt langaz
tgt_lang: "Among the grammars falling into the family of oral grammar, we find: sentence grammar, discourse grammar, language act grammar"

src_lang: (iii) Gramer text Gramer text, li enn prolonzman alafwa gramer striktiral (ki interes li ek letid bann fraz) ek gramer laparol (ki interes li ek letid bann enonse dan sitiasion kominikasion kot zot finn prodir)
tgt_lang: "(iii) Grammar text Grammar text, it is a combination of strictural grammar (which is concerned with the structure and study of sentences) and functional grammar (which is concerned with the analysis of utterances in communication situations where they are produced)"

src_lang: Li met an evidans bann kriter ek striktir ki determinn koerans enn text
tgt_lang: It highlights the criteria and structures that determine the coherence of a text

src_lang: Term itilize an lingwistik enonsiasion pou dezign enn mesaz oral ou ekri ki finn prodir dan enn sitiasion kominikasion
tgt_lang: Terms used in linguistic enunciation to design an oral or written message that has been produced in a communication situation

src_lang: Gramer modern an konparezon ek gramer tradisionel Pou revinn an detay lor bann premie gramer ki finn pran zot distans ek gramer tradisionel, anou get ansam ki bann karakteristik ki diferansie zot
tgt_lang: "Modern grammar in comparison with traditional grammar To delve into the first grammars that have taken their distance from and traditional grammar, let's look at together the characteristics that differentiate them"

src_lang: Karakteristik gramer striktiral: (i) Zot plis deskriptif ki normatif Alor ki gramer tradisionel, li normatif (get pli lao), bann gramer modern, inspire par bann demars obzektivite ek siantifisite ki lingwistik modern finn met an avan, finn adopte enn demars ki align li plis lor deskripsion bann pratik reel bann itilizater enn lang pou dekrir so gramer plito ki pratik ki inpoze par bann teorisien
tgt_lang: "Characteristics of structural grammar: (i) They are more descriptive than normative While traditional grammar is normative (or more prescriptive), modern grammars, inspired by approaches of objectivity and scientificity that modern linguistics have put forward, have adopted an approach that aligns more with describing the real practices of language users to describe its grammar rather than practices imposed by theorists"

src_lang: Zot pa kon sidere ki ena bann pratik ki siperyer par rapor ar bann lezot pratik
tgt_lang: They do not consider that there are practices superior to others

src_lang: Zot zis konstate ki ena diferan pratik langaz dan sosiete e zot dekrir sa bann diferan pratik‐la an relasion ar sitiasion ek kontext kot servi zot
tgt_lang: They simply note that there are different language practices in society and they describe these different practices in relation to the situation and context they are used in

src_lang: Se pou sa rezon‐la ousi ki oral pran souvan plis linportans ki lekritir da n bann gramer modern
tgt_lang: For this reason, oral communication often takes on more importance than written communication in modern grammars

src_lang: (ii) Zot akord plis linportans laparol ki lekritir Etan done ki dan ninport ki lang natirel, volim prodikion langaz li infiniman pli elve onivo oral ki onivo lekritir (sof pou bann lang ki finn deza mor, me ki dimounn ankor pe etidie pou diferan rezon) gramer modern baz so bann analiz boukou plis lor bann pratik oral plito ki ba nn pratik lekritir
tgt_lang: "(ii) They give more importance to oral than written communication Given that in any natural language, the volume of language production is infinitely higher at the oral level than at the written level (except for languages that are already dead, but which are still being studied for various reasons) modern grammar bases its analyses much more on oral practices than on written practices"

src_lang: Sa karakteristik ‐la, li ankor pli vre dan ka bann lang kreol, ki bann lang modern e ki finn fonksionn sirtou kouma bann lang oral ziska ler
tgt_lang: "This characteristic is even truer for creole languages, modern languages that have primarily functioned as oral languages up until now"

src_lang: Me, dan ka bann lang kreol, e pli spesifiKreol Morisyenan lang Kreol Morisyen, morfolozi li ena kanmem enn gran linportans kan nou etidie bann prosede formasion ek kreasion bann mo, seki sinta x, dan so kote, pa permet fer
tgt_lang: "In the case of creole languages, and more specifically Mauritian Creole language, morphology has great importance when studying the formation processes and creation of words, such as x, in its place, do not allow making"

src_lang: Apre tou seki nou finn trouve, nou panse ki ena plizier fason pou definir gramer, depandan dan ki kontext nou ete, e lor ki laspe nou pe anvi met plis linportans
tgt_lang: "After all that we have found, we think that there are several ways to define grammar, depending on the context we are in, and at the moment when we want to give more importance"

src_lang: Rezime lor definision gramer:
tgt_lang: Summary on the definition of grammar:

src_lang: Dan enn demars operatwar rapid, li posib definir gramer kouma: Letid siantifik bann striktir enn lang
tgt_lang: "In a rapid operational approach, it is possible to define grammar as: The scientific study of the strictures of a language"

src_lang: Me ena ousi lezot definision ki bon retenir dan kad lexersis ki nou pe fer isi:
tgt_lang: But there are also other definitions worth noting in the exercises we are doing here:

src_lang: Enn gramer fer referans lansanb bann reg ki permet konbinn bann inite lingwistik ki ena dan enn lang, e ki permet zo t fer bann fraz ki dimounn servi kan zot exprim zot atraver bann enonse
tgt_lang: "A grammar serves as a reference to the set of rules that allow combining the linguistic units present in a language, and that enable the construction of sentences that people use when expressing themselves"

src_lang: Tou bann lang ena enn gramer, sinon dimounn pa ti pou kapav servi zot pou koze
tgt_lang: "All languages ​​have a grammar, otherwise people would not be able to use them to communicate"

src_lang: Gramer vedir ousi enn deskripsion, enn fason pou reper bann striktir lang‐la dapre enn (b ann) teori spesifik ek propoz enn fason pou analiz striktir‐la ek so fonskionnman dapre sa (bann) teori‐la
tgt_lang: "Grammar also means a description, a way to identify the strictures of a language according to a specific theory and propose a way to analyze its structure and functioning according to that theory"

src_lang: Ena fason tradisionel pou analiz gramer enn lang, ena metod striktiral, ki pli modern
tgt_lang: "There is a traditional way to analyze the grammar of a language, a structural method, and a more modern one"

src_lang: Me ena ousi lezot lapros kouma gramer laparol (parmi, gramer lenonsiasion), gramer text, etc
tgt_lang: "But there are also other approaches such as oral grammar (including sentence grammar), textual grammar, etc"

src_lang: Bann gramer modern ena tandans etidie ba nn lang dan bann fason pli deskriptif ek obzektif alor ki gramer tradisionel ena tandans pou pli preskriptif ek normatif
tgt_lang: Modern grammar tends to study languages in a more descriptive and objective manner, while traditional grammar tends to be more prescriptive and normative.

src_lang: Dan kad lekol, kot kapav ansegn bann zelev gramer enn sel lang, ouswa plizier lang anmemtan, lapros normatif ek preskriptif ena tandans prime
tgt_lang: "In the school context, where students can learn grammar of one or more languages at the same time, normative and prescriptive approaches tend to prevail."

src_lang: Nosion fot gramer itilize dan sa ka‐la, swa parski analiz enn fraz finn mal fer, swa parski fraz‐la finn ekrir (ou finn dir) dan enn fason ki pa an‐akor ek bann reg lang‐la
tgt_lang: "The notion of grammar mistakes are used in this case either because the analysis of a sentence has been poorly done, or because the sentence was written (or spoken) in a way that is not in accordance with the rules of the language."

src_lang: Dan kad lekol touzour, nou souvan konsevwar enn gramer dan form enn maniel kot finn ekrir ek dekrir bann reg (deskrptif ou preskriptif) enn lang avek bann exersis pou zelev pratike
tgt_lang: "In the school setting, we often keep a grammar in the form of a manual where the rules (descriptive or prescriptive) of a language are written and described, with exercises for students to practice."

src_lang: BANN LETID LOR STRIKTIR KREOL MORISIEN Bann letid lingwistik lor Kreol Morisyen finn fer selon bann perspektiv lingwistik varye: fonetik, lexikolozik, sintaxik, sosiolingwistik, etc
tgt_lang: "LINGUISTIC STUDIES ON MAURITIAN CREOLE Linguistic studies on Mauritian Creole have been conducted from various linguistic perspectives: phonetic, lexical, syntactic, sociolinguistic, etc."

src_lang: Zot reprezant enn poursantaz bien for par rapor ek totalite letid ki finn fer lor bann lang Moris: plis ki % en (Police), alor ki bann letid lor sitiasion miltileng ek lor Franse ki ariv an em pozision, reprezant sakenn % (touzour selon letid mem lepok)
tgt_lang: "They represent a strong percentage compared to the total studies done on Mauritian languages: over 50% in (Creole), while studies on multilingual situations and on French, which are also influential, represent each a percentage (according to studies of the same period)."

src_lang: Bann lanaliz lor striktir Kreol Morisyen remont ziska , dat piblikasion Étude sur le patois créole de Maurice par Baissac
tgt_lang: "Analyses on the structure of Mauritian Creole go back to , the publication of Étude sur le patois créole de Maurice by Baissac."

src_lang: Biensir li adopte enn lapros tradisionel selon lideolozi kolonial sa lepok‐la: li pa konsider Kreol kouma enn lang e seki finn motiv so letid, se ofer enn divertisman komin ote siantifik internasional
tgt_lang: "Of course, it adopted a traditional approach in line with colonial ideology of the time: it did not consider Creole as a language and the motivation behind its studies was to provide entertainment rather than international scientific insight."

src_lang: Toutfwa, piblikasion Baissac res enn referans an rezon lintere ki li reprezante pou analiz striktir Kreol Morisyen kouma li ti ete e siek
tgt_lang: "However, Baissac's publication remains a reference for the interest it represents in analyzing the structure of Mauritian Creole as it was then."

src_lang: Enn repertwar diakronik montre ki bann letid lor Kreol Morisyen antan ki enn lang dan so plin drwa, komanse avek devlopman lingwistik modern ki demare avek piblikasion an , Cours de linguistique générale
tgt_lang: "A diachronic repertoire shows that studies on Mauritian Creole as a full-fledged language began with the modern linguistic development that started with the publication of , Course in General Linguistics."

src_lang: Sa piblikasion ‐la fer par de etidian apartir kour zot profeser ki finn desede an : Ferdinand de Saussure
tgt_lang: This publication is made up of two studies from their professor's course which has passed away: Ferdinand de Saussure

src_lang: Par so bann kou r iniversiter, Saussure inn amenn bann sanzman desizif dan perspektiv analiz ek definision enn lang
tgt_lang: "Through his university courses, Saussure brought decisive innovations into the field of analysis and definition of a language."

src_lang: An efe, par so travay, Saussure finn valoriz enn perspektiv sinkronik alor ki, avan li, bann filolog (bann dimounn ki etidie enn lang apartir bann text ansien) ti pe donn priyorite dan zot lanaliz, evolision ek zenealozi ba nn lang
tgt_lang: "In fact, through his work, Saussure has valorized a synchronic perspective while, before him, philologists (people who study a language from ancient texts) were giving priority in their analysis, evolution, and genealogy to a language."

src_lang: Perspektiv ki Saussure finn adopte finn permet li, prinsipalman, met an evidans ki miltiplisite varyasion ki kapav ena dan pratik enn lang par enn kominote imin, sa bann varyasion ‐la repoz lor enn nonb limite bann sign lingwistik
tgt_lang: "The perspective that Saussure adopted has allowed him, mainly, to highlight that the multiple variations that can exist in a language within a human community, these variations are based on a limited number of linguistic signs."

src_lang: Sa bann sign‐la fer parti enn rezo relasion ki organiz zot sou form enn striktir, enn sistem
tgt_lang: "These signs are part of a relational network that organizes them in a strict form, a system."

src_lang: Se kou msa ki Saussure definir enn lang kouma enn sistem sign e ki li finn donn nesans, par so travay, lingwistik striktiral
tgt_lang: "It is through this that Saussure defines a language as a sign system and that, through his work, he has given birth to structural linguistics."

src_lang: Bann lingwist inpe partou dan lemond pou koumans montre enn lintere pou bann lang kreol apartir , prinsipalman akoz sertin pwin komin ki sa bann lang‐la prezante onivo zot striktir e lokazion exsepsionel ki ena pou fer bann letid lor kontext zot nesans: ki landrwa ek ki lepok zot finn pran nesans, kisan n‐la ti prezan
tgt_lang: "Linguists are showing an interest in Creole languages almost everywhere in the world, mainly because of certain common points that these languages present at the level of their structure and exceptional location that makes them interesting for contextual analysis of their origin: where and when they were born, who was present."

src_lang: Zot finn trouve ki bann pwin komin onivo striktir bann lang kreol explike par bann pwin komin ant bann kontext kot zot finn pran nesans: bann lang kreol finn ne an zeneral lor bann lil (sof dan ka Louisianne, Guinée Bissau ek Guyanne), dan bann sosiete es klavazis kot ena bann plantasion (kann, kafe ou koton)
tgt_lang: "They found that the common points at the structural level of Creole languages are explained by the common points between the contexts where they originated: Creole languages are generally born on islands (except in cases like Louisiana, Guinea-Bissau, and Guyana), in societies where there are plantations (sugarcane, coffee, or cotton)."

src_lang: LAPROS MORFOLOZIK An zeneral, kan nou koz morfolozi, premie zafer ki interes nou, se bann mo ki ena dan enn lang
tgt_lang: "MORPHOLOGICAL PROPOSITIONS In general, when we talk about morphology, the first thing that interests us is the words in a language"

src_lang: Me ena de fason etidie bann mo enn lang lor plan morfolozik
tgt_lang: But there are two ways to study words in a language on a morphological level

src_lang: Enn premie fason kot nou etidie manier bann mo sanz form dan lang‐la, an fonksion diferan kriter ek diferan konte xt
tgt_lang: "A first way in which we study how words change form in the language, depending on different criteria and contexts"

src_lang: Nou apel sa: morfolozi flexionel
tgt_lang: We call this: inflectional morphology

src_lang: Ena enn deziem fason, kot nou interes nou ek manier kot bann mo (finn) kree dan lang‐la selon diferan prosede
tgt_lang: "There's also a second way, where we focus on the way words (have) been created in the language using different processes"

src_lang: Nou apel sa: morfolozi derivasionel
tgt_lang: We call this: derivational morphology

src_lang: Me ena ousi bann lezot prosede kreasion mo dan enn lang
tgt_lang: But there are also other ways of creating words in a language

src_lang: Parmi, ena: transkategorizasion , konpozision , rediplikasion , anprin et neolozism
tgt_lang: "Among them are: trans categorization, composition, reduplication, borrowing, and neologism"

src_lang: Morfolozi flexionel Dan enn premie tan, nou interese par manier bann mo‐la kapav sanz form alinteryer enn mem kategori gramatikal, an fonkson sertin kriter gramatikal kouma nonb (pliryel ek singilie), zanr (maskilin, feminin); personn ( e, em, em), etc
tgt_lang: "In the beginning, we are interested in the way words can change forms within the same grammatical category, based on certain grammatical criteria such as number (plural and singular), gender (masculine, feminine), person (he, she, it), etc"

src_lang: Anou pran, kouma enn lexanp, enn lang kouma Franse
tgt_lang: "Let's take, for example, a language like French"

src_lang: Selon ki enn azektif li singile ouswa pliryel, selon ki li maskilin ouswa feminin, li pa pou ekrir parey
tgt_lang: "Depending on whether an adjective is singular or plural, masculine or feminine, it will not be written the same way"

src_lang: Long, par exanp, ki maskilin singilie an Franse (“un long baton”), vinn longue kan li feminin singilie “une longue robe”, longs kan li maskilin pliryel (“de longs batons ”), longues kan li feminin pliryel (“de longues robes”)
tgt_lang: "Long, for example, is masculine singular in French ("un long baton"), becomes longue when feminine singular ("une longue robe"), longs when masculine plural ("de longs batons"), longues when feminine plural ("de longues robes")"

src_lang: Nou dir ki li enn mo varyab
tgt_lang: We say that it is a variable word

src_lang: Dan enn lang kouma Kreol Morisyen par kont, azektif ‘long’ napa sanz form dan okenn kontext gramatikal
tgt_lang: "In a language like Mauritian Creole, however, the adjective 'long' does not change form in any grammatical context"

src_lang: Nou dir ki mo‐la, li invaryab
tgt_lang: "We say that here it is invariable"

src_lang: Kan nou interes nou ek sa tip letid‐la, nou pe fer ‘mor folozi flexionel ’
tgt_lang: "When we are interested in this type of study, we are doing 'morphological inflection'"

src_lang: Dan Kreol Morisyen kouma dan boukou lezot lang kreol, morfolozi flexionel pena gran rol parski varyasion form bann mo an fonksion kriter gramatikal, an zeneral li pa existe, sof dan sertin ka
tgt_lang: "In Mauritian Creole, as in many other Creole languages, morphological inflection does not play a big role because variations in the forms of words depend on grammatical criteria, generally it does not exist, except in some cases"

src_lang: Sa mo‐la, se ‘bann’ : ‘b ann zanfan, enn bann zanfan, sa bann zanfan‐ la’
tgt_lang: "This, I, define as 'bann': 'children, a group of children, those children'"

src_lang: (iii) Distinksion letan dan bann verb ousi pena onivo zot form
tgt_lang: (iii) There is no distinction in Creole verbs for time, and they don't have different forms either

src_lang: ‘Ale’, ‘vini’, ‘marse’ ekrir parey, ki nou dan prezan (‘mo pe ale/vini/ marse’), ki nou dan pase (‘mo ti ale / ti vini / ti marse’) , ouswa dan fitir (‘mo pou ale / pou vini / pou marse’)
tgt_lang: " 'Go', 'come', 'walk' are written the same, what we are in the present ('I am going/coming/walking'), what we were in the past ('I went/came/walked'), or in the future ('I will go/come/walk')"

src_lang: Sel alternans ki bann verb kone dan Kreol Morisyen, se onivo zot form, Ena enn form long (ouswa plin) ki servi kan verb‐la otonom
tgt_lang: "The only alternation in Creole verbs is in their form. There is a long (or full) form that is used when the verb is autonomous"

src_lang: Setadir kot, an zeneral, li pena enn konpleman: ‘mo pe ale, to pe vini, li pe marse’
tgt_lang: "Meaning, in general, it does not have a complement: 'I am going, you are coming, he is walking'"

src_lang: Ena enn form kourt (ou swa medial ) ki servi kan verb‐la antrenn enn konpleman: ‘mo pe al lakaz, to ti vinn lekol, li ti pe mars dan zardin’
tgt_lang: "There is a short (or medial) form that is used when the verb takes a complement: 'I am going home, you were coming to school, he was walking in the garden'"

src_lang: Par exanp: chek‐cheke , dibout‐diboute , koulout‐kouloute , lastik‐lastike , louk‐louke , etc
tgt_lang: "For example: search-seek, stand up-stand, roll-roll, elastic-elastic, lock-lock, etc."

tgt_lang: "Forward; Corpooran, (sent in the introduction of the Mauritian Dictionary)"

src_lang: Morfolozi derivasionel Morfolozi derivasionel, dan so kote, li interes li ek manier ki bann mo enn lang forme, swa apartir bann mo ki deza existe, swa apartir bann lezot prosede
tgt_lang: "Derivational morphology. Derivational morphology, in its place, is interested in the ways in which words in a language are formed, either from existing words or from other procedures"

src_lang: Derivasion avek prefix Enn mo kapav deriv lor enn lot mo zis parski nou finn azout enn prefix ek li
tgt_lang: Derivation with a prefix. A word can be derived from another word with a prefix because we added a prefix to it.

src_lang: Derivasion avek sifix Nou pou met isi sirtou bann sifix ki (finn) permet fabrik bann mo nouvo an Kreol Morisyen, setadir ki nou pa pe pran kont bann mo ki finn sorti direkteman depi enn lot lang deza ek zot sifix
tgt_lang: Derivation with suffixes We will put here especially the suffixes that have allowed us to create new words in Mauritian Creole, meaning that we are not taking into account words that have directly come from another language and their suffixes

src_lang: Me prinsip‐la, li aplike ek tou bann ka kot kapav separ enn mo kre ol ek enn lot mo kreol zis par prezans ouswa absans enn sifix
tgt_lang: "But the principle is to apply to all cases where a word in Creole can be separated from another Creole word just by the presence or absence of a suffix"

src_lang: Par exanp, faner (dan sans ‘dimounn ki azir mal ouswa dan enn fason maladrwa’) forme apartir verb kreol fane (setadir dan sans ‘azir mal ouswa dan enn fason maladrwa’) ek sifix azan ‐er
tgt_lang: "For example, famer (in the sense of 'a person who acts badly or in a cunning manner') is formed from the Creole verb fane (meaning 'to act badly or in a cunning manner') and the suffix -er"

src_lang: LAPROS ENONSIASION
tgt_lang: LINGUISTIC ENUNCIATION

src_lang: So lorizinn ek so prinsip analiz Lingwistik enonsiasion abord analiz bann form ek striktir lingwistik selon perspektiv sibzektif dimounn ki itiliz zot dan enn sitiasion kominikasion
tgt_lang: Its origin and its principle of linguistic analysis enunciation approach analyzes forms and linguistic structures from the subjective perspective of the person who uses them in a communication situation

src_lang: Dan sa volim‐la, nou pe fer enn prezantasion bann form lingwistik ki ransegn nou lor manier ki enn lokiter pran an sarz seki li pe dir; setadir manier ki li definir limem ek dimounn ar ki li pe koze dan so parol, manie r ki li sitie seki li pe dir par rapor ar moman ek landrwa kot li pe koze
tgt_lang: "In this volume, we are giving a presentation of linguistic forms that shed light on the way a speaker expresses what he is saying: meaning how he defines himself and the person with whom he is speaking in his words, and the way he situates what he is saying in relation to the time and place where he is speaking"

src_lang: Lingwistik enonsiasion finn devlope apartir travay enn lingwist franse, Emile Benveniste dan so piblikasion Problèmes de linguistique générale (Tom , ; Tom , )
tgt_lang: "Linguistic enunciation developed from the work of a French linguist, Emile Benveniste, in his publication Problèmes de linguistique générale (Vol. , ; Vol. , )"

src_lang: Ladan, li reg roup enn seri text ki fer enn kritik devlopma ki teori Ferdinand de Saussure finn kone avek sertin lingwist amerikin
tgt_lang: "In it, he revisits a series of texts that critique the development of the theory that Ferdinand de Saussure had established with certain American linguists"

src_lang: Émile Benveniste, enn disip Ferdinand de Saussure
tgt_lang: "Emile Benveniste, a disciple of Ferdinand de Saussure"

src_lang: Par bann text ki li finn pibliye, li finn oule reazir kont devlopman exsesif ki sertin lingwist amerikin finn donn striktiralism: zot finn akord tro linportans dan zot analiz, konbinezon bann form lingwistik desort ki zot finn negliz dimansion semantik ek lorizinn imin ki definir enn lang
tgt_lang: "Through the texts he published, he expressed dissatisfaction with the excessive development that certain American linguists had given to structuralism: they gave too much importance to their analysis, leaving out the semantic dimension and the content that defines a language"

src_lang: An reaksi on, Émile Benveniste finn propoz enn perspektiv analiz ki replas imin dan sant preokipasion bann lingwist
tgt_lang: "In reaction, Émile Benveniste proposed an analytical perspective that replaces the notion of the speaker with the focal concern of linguists."

src_lang: Li finn osi swazir pou analiz enn lang tel ki li pratike dan larealite: enn laspe konplemanter par rapor ar lapros Saussure, kot li, li montre ki enn lang enn sistem virtiel ki exist e zis an term konpetans lingwistik kan pa pe itiliz li
tgt_lang: "He also chose to analyze a language such as the one he practices in reality: a complete complement to Saussure's approach, where he demonstrates that a language is a virtual system that exists only in linguistic competence when not used."

src_lang: Benveniste telman pertinan dan so demars rektifikasion ki so bann piblikasion finn donn nesans ‘teori enonsiasion’ ki form soubasman seki nou apel zordi ‘lingwistik enonsiasion’
tgt_lang: Benveniste's rectifying approach has been so pertinent that his publications gave rise to the ‘theory of enunciation’ which forms the basis of what we now call ‘enunciative linguistics.’

src_lang: Benveniste met an evidans lefet ki kan enn dimounn koze dan larealite, li itiliz bann form ek striktir lingwistik ki li kone e li re‐organiz zot selon so perspektiv sibzektif pou prodir bann parol ki fer sans onivo lekritir ouswa onivo oral
tgt_lang: "Benveniste highlights the fact that when a person speaks in reality, they utulize strict linguistic forms known to them and reorganize them according to their subjective perspective to produce words that make sense at both a literary and oral level."

src_lang: Bann lingwist konsider travay Benveniste plito kouma enn lapros antropolozik fak ilte langaz
tgt_lang: Linguists consider Benveniste's work more as an anthropological approach to language

src_lang: Plitar, bann lingwist kouma Maingueneau, Culioli ek Kerbrat‐ Orecchioni, pou zeneraliz so lapros e met an evidans nesesite fer distinksion ant, enn kote, itilizasion bann form ek striktir lingwistik an relasion avek sitiasion enonsiasion ek lot kote, lezot tip itilizasion
tgt_lang: "Most notably, linguists such as Maingueneau, Culioli, and Kerbrat‐Orecchioni, seek to generalize his approach and emphasize the need to distinguish between, on one hand, using linguistic forms strictly in relation to enunciative situations and on the other, different types of uses."

src_lang: Deskripsion lingwist franse Antoine Culioli ( ) ek so lekip bien explisit par nos ion ‘reperaz’ ki zot servi pou definir diferan tip relasion ki enn lokiter etablir ant seki li pe dezigne ek so sitiasion kominikasion
tgt_lang: The French linguist Antoine Culioli ( ) and his team explain explicitly through their work on ‘references’ used to define different types of relationships established between what is being referred to and its communicative situation

src_lang: Zot finn travay lor bann aktivite langaz tel ki zot revele par bann form ki itilize dan enn enonse
tgt_lang: They worked on language activities such as those revealed by the forms used in a speech

src_lang: An efe, kan enn lokiter itiliz bann form lingwistik par rapor ar so sitiasion kominikasion, li pe literalman donn bann reper lor ki manier li sitie limem ek so interlokiter, kouma li pe ousi sitie seki li pe dir par rapor ar sa sitiasion‐la
tgt_lang: "Indeed, when a speaker uses linguistic forms in relation to their communicative situation, they are literally providing references on how they position themselves and their interlocutors, as well as how they position what they are saying in relation to that situation."

src_lang: Ena trwa tip reperaz ki enn lokiter kapav fer:
tgt_lang: There are three types of references that a speaker can make:

src_lang: Reperaz ki ena enn valer idantifikasion parski li ekivo ar bann pwin referans sitiasion kominikasion
tgt_lang: There is a value of identification as it is on par with the win situation communication references.

src_lang: Lokiter‐la itiliz enn form lingwistik ki fer referans ar limem, moman enonsiasion ou lespas enonsiasion
tgt_lang: "The speaker uses a linguistic form that makes references to the speech, the moment of enunciation, or the space of enunciation"

src_lang: Exanp: ‘mo’ dan ‘mo pe vini’ ki fer referans ar lokiter
tgt_lang: Example: 'mo' in 'mo pe vini' which refers to the speaker

src_lang: Reperaz ki ena enn valer diferans iasion
tgt_lang: There is a different value of enunciation.

src_lang: Lokiter‐la pe itiliz bann form lingwistik ki signale ki seki li pe dezigne, li diferan me res an relasion ar limem, moman enonsiasion ou lespas enonsiasion
tgt_lang: "The speaker uses linguistic forms that signal what he is designating, it is different but also in relation to speech, the moment of enunciation or the space of enunciation"

src_lang: Exanp: ‘to’ dan ‘to pe vini’ ki fer referans ar dimounn avek ki lokiter an relasion kan li pe koze
tgt_lang: Example: 'to' in 'to pe vini' which refers to the person the speaker is speaking with.

src_lang: Text oral ou ekri ki finn prodir dan enn sitiasion kominikasion
tgt_lang: Oral or written text that has been produced in a communication situation.

src_lang: Reperaz ki ena enn valer riptir
tgt_lang: There is a value of repetition.

src_lang: Lokiter‐la pe itiliz bann form lingwistik ki signale ki seki li pe dezigne, li diferan ek li osi an riptir ar limem, moman enonsiasion ou lespas enonsiasion
tgt_lang: "The speaker uses linguistic forms that signal what he is designating, it is different and also in repetition with speech, the moment of enunciation or the space of enunciation"

src_lang: Exanp: ‘li’ dan ‘li pe vini’ ki fer referans ar dimounn lor ki lokiter pe koze e avek ki li pena okenn relasion kan li pe koz e
tgt_lang: Example: 'li' in 'li pe vini' which refers to the person the speaker is talking about and with whom he has no relationship when he is speaking.

src_lang: Kerbrat‐ Orecchini ( ) osi explisit kan li swazir pou itiliz nosion ‘lokalizasion tanporel’ ek ‘lokalizasion spasial’ pou signifie ki ‘letan’ ek ‘lepas’ striktire apartir enn pwin referans: aktivite langaz bann lokiter
tgt_lang: Kerbrat-Orecchini also explicitly explains when he chooses to use the notions 'temporal localization' and 'spatial localization' to imply what 'time' and 'space' strictly mean from a reference point: language activities of speakers

src_lang: Nou pou ousi servi bann teori ki Vandeloise inn prezante pou dekrir lespas an Fr anse ek nou pou adapte li pou nou deskripsion lespas (sapit )
tgt_lang: We will also use the theories presented by Vandeloise to describe space in French and adapt it for our description of space (knowledge)

src_lang: Lintere teori enonsiasion pou enn deskripsion Kreol Morisien Teori enonsiasion partikilierman efikas pou rann kont bann form ek striktir ki disponib dan enn lang spesifik, pou ki enn dimounn devlop e perfeksionn bann laspe fondamantal so fakilte langaz dan enn sitiasion kominikasion
tgt_lang: "The interest of enunciation theory for a description of Mauritian Creole Enunciation theory is particularly efficient in highlighting the forms and structures available in a specific language, allowing an individual to develop and perfect the fundamental aspects of their language faculty in a communicative situation"

src_lang: Seki bann lingwist apel fakilte langaz, li enn fakilte kognitif ki komin pou tou dimounn
tgt_lang: "What linguists call language faculty is a cognitive faculty common to all individuals"

src_lang: Sa fakilte‐la devlope prog resivman ek natirelman avek lexperyans, kan enn zanfan pe aprann koze
tgt_lang: "This faculty develops progressively and naturally through experience when a child is learning language"

src_lang: Lansegnman/aprantisaz sa lang‐la dan enn kontext formel kouma lekol, permet enn lokiter pran konsians tou bann resours disponib dan sa lang‐la pou ki li devlop pli rapidman bann konpetans kominikasion deplizanpli varye ek konplex insi ki so bann kon petans pou aprann plizier lang
tgt_lang: "Teaching/learning this language in a formal context such as school allows an individual to become aware of all the resources available in the language so that they can develop communicative skills more rapidly and diversely complex as well as their abilities to learn multiple languages"

src_lang: Parmi bann laspe fakilte langaz ki enn imin bizin devlope, ena so konpetans pou exprim li apartir bann referans ki definir so sitiasion kominikasion: ‐ referans interlokiter: lokiter/kololiter (an Kreol Morisyen ‘mo’/ ‘to’; ‘mwa’/ ‘twa’)
tgt_lang: "Among the aspects of the language faculty that a child must develop, there is the competence to express oneself based on references that define their communicative situation: - interlocutor reference: speaker/listener (in Mauritian Creole 'mwe'/'toa'; 'mo'/'to')"

src_lang: ‐ referans moman kot lokiter inskrir so parol (‘aster’ ) ki li pou servi pou sitie, repere ou lokaliz seki li pe dir dan letan ‐ referans landrwa kot lokiter inskrir so parol (‘isi’) ki li pou servi pou sitie, repere ou lokaliz seki li pe dir dan lespas
tgt_lang: "- moment reference where the speaker marks their speech ('here') which they use to situate, locate, or localize what they are saying in time - location reference where the speaker marks their speech ('here') which they use to situate, locate, or localize what they are saying in space"

src_lang: Sa konpetans ‐la, li fondamantal, parski li esansielman an referans ar sitiasion komi nikasion ki enn dimounn kapav, enn kote, prodir enn parol (oral ou ekri) ki ena sans, e lot kote, konpran parol (oral ou ekri) ki li pe ekoute ou lir
tgt_lang: "This competence is fundamental because it is essentially in reference to the communicative situation that an individual can, in one place, produce a speech (oral or written) that is meaningful, and in another place, understand a speech (oral or written) they are listening to or reading"

src_lang: Pli inportan ankor, se dan lexersis laparol an sitiasion reel kominikasion ki enn dimounn: ‐ definir, pran k onsians ek devlop so lidantite/personalite dan enn rezo relasion familial e sosial ‐ definir, pran konsians ek striktir letan ek lespas ki karakteriz lavi imin, kondisionn so lekilib mantal e rann posib so lavi dan sosiete
tgt_lang: "Even more importantly, it is through the practice of speaking in real communicative situations that an individual: - defines, becomes aware of, and develops their identity/personality in a network of familial and social relations - defines, becomes aware of, and strictly delimits the time and space that characterize their life, conditions their mental equilibrium, and makes it possible for them to live in society"

src_lang: INTERLOKISION Enn sitiasion kominikasion, li definir neseserman par enn dimounn ki pran laparol pou adres li ar enn lot dimounn
tgt_lang: "INTERLOCUTION is a communication situation, defined by a person who takes the floor to address another person."

src_lang: Seki pran laparol, nou apel li ‘lokiter’ e dimounn ar ki lokiter pe adres li, nou ava apel sa dimounn ‐la ‘kololiter’ parski dan enn sitiasion interlokision, toule de aktif: swa pou koze, swa po u ekout ek interpret parol ki pe tande ou lir
tgt_lang: "The one who takes the floor, we call him 'interlocutor' and the person with whom the interlocutor is engaging, we will call that person the 'co-interlocutor' because in an interlocution situation, both are active: either to speak, or to listen and interpret the words being heard or read."

src_lang: De plis, bann rol lokiter ek kololiter napa bann rol fix: sakenn so tour pran rol lokiter kan li pran laparol; dan sa ka‐la, lot dimounn, ki pa pe koze me ki pe ekoute, pran rol kololiter
tgt_lang: "Furthermore, the roles of interlocutor and co-interlocutor are not fixed roles: each person takes on the role of interlocutor when they speak; in this case, the other person, who is not speaking but listening, takes on the role of co-interlocutor."

src_lang: Nou ava ap el zot toulede ‘interlokiter’
tgt_lang: We will now call you both 'interlocutors.'

src_lang: Bien evidaman, lexperyans montre ki kapav ena plizier lokiter (mem si li ase rar) e plizier interlokiter (seki arive souvan)
tgt_lang: "Clearly, experience shows that there can be multiple interlocutors (although rare) and multiple co-interlocutors (those that occur frequently)."

src_lang: Deza dan so bann piblikasion ( , ) ki a lorizinn lingwistik enonsiasion, Benveniste finn met an evidans laparol kouma enn landrwa kot sibzektivite enn dimounn manifeste
tgt_lang: "Already in his linguistic publications, Benveniste has highlighted speech as a battlefield where a person's subjectivity manifests itself."
